overview.short: Photorhabdus species are Gram-negative, facultatively anaerobic rods known for their bioluminescence and symbiotic association with entomopathogenic nematodes.
overview.clinical_context: Rare but notable human pathogens, primarily associated with wound infections and septicemia following insect exposure.

field_notes.Colony Morphology: Bioluminescence is a hallmark feature, best observed in dark conditions.
field_notes.DNase: DNase positivity is common and helps differentiate from other Enterobacterales.
field_notes.Motility: Non-motility distinguishes Photorhabdus from many other Gram-negative rods.

key_differentiators.notes: Natural bioluminescence is a defining and rare trait among human pathogens.
DNase positivity supports Photorhabdus over common Enterobacterales.
Non-motility helps separate Photorhabdus from other environmental Gram-negative rods.

common_confusions.reason: Overlapping biochemical reactions on routine media.
Shared DNase positivity and environmental origin.

when_to_question_identification: Absence of bioluminescence suggests another genus.
Strong lactose fermentation argues against Photorhabdus.
Motility positivity is inconsistent with the genus.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Supports differentiation from other Gram-negative rods.
Reliable identification for rare and unusual pathogens.
